answer1.text: The important thing is to remove all evidence of the cooking process. Customers come to classy restaurants to a) avoid the exhaustion of food preparation and b) feel cultured for eating out. Don't remind them of something so low brow as labor.

This isn't really that kind of forum site. If you want to ask more personal questions like that, put it in global messages! Ask questions that need solving, or otherwise present some kind of interesting culinary conundrum!
But for the record, I love hand pulled noodles.

answer3.text: Kimchi is meant to be an exhausting process. Even if you buy the mix, the fermenting process will take forever. If you're already taking shortcuts, just buy storebought.

answer4.text: Make a friend with a backyard grill or give up. The experience is half of it. The smoke alone from a proper grilling would make you public enemy #1.

answer5.text: I recommend having your syrup on the side, so that it won't sink into your waffle and you can have the best possible syrup amount per bite. Try and enjoy!

answer6.text: 100%. If you're trying to move to a semi-professional scale operation you need to mechanize some of the labor or else it's going to take a prohibitive amount of time. Best of luck with the business!

answer7.text: You can't cook rice normally in it, but if you got rice from somewhere else you could do fried rice. If you own a microwave find microwavable rice and go wild.

answer8.text: Go for white-fleshed fish, otherwise they're too oily/ flavorful. Halibut, cod, some examples.

answer9.text: I always swear by butter instead of olive oil. It makes the resulting eggs practically melt in your mouth.
